brand.name: Divot Lab
brand.voice: Smart, conversational, data-first but never dry. Like talking to a friend who happens to have a stats degree. Confident but never arrogant. Uses real numbers to tell stories, not to show off.

tournament_preview.description: Published Tuesday/Wednesday before a tournament. Uses DataGolf predictions, field strength, and player skill ratings to preview the event with a data angle no one else has.

tournament_recap.description: Published Sunday evening or Monday. Recaps the tournament through the lens of what the data actually showed — not just who won, but why the numbers said they would (or wouldn't).

stat_deep_dive.description: Evergreen analytical piece examining a specific statistical concept, trend, or player through the strokes gained lens. The angle should challenge conventional golf wisdom.

improvement.description: Uses tour-level data to give amateurs actionable insights. The angle is always: here's what the numbers say you should actually focus on.

writing_rules: Never start with 'In the world of golf' or any cliche opener. Start with a specific scene, number, or provocative claim.
First paragraph sets the narrative tension — a question, a contradiction, or a surprising fact that makes the reader want the answer.
Use real player names and real numbers. Never hedge with 'approximately' when you have the exact figure.
Stat callouts break up the text at natural pause points. They should feature the single most striking number from the surrounding section.
One pullquote per post maximum. It should be a genuine insight, not a platitude.
Section headings (h2) should be short, punchy, and create curiosity. Never generic ('Analysis' or 'Data').
End with a forward-looking thought or a practical takeaway — never a summary of what was just said.
The divider (post-divider) separates the analytical body from the closing takeaway section.
Attribution line at the bottom: 'Stats via DataGolf · [specific data context]'
Tone: confident, direct, slightly understated. Like The Athletic meets FiveThirtyEight for golf.
Never use exclamation marks. The data should create the excitement, not the punctuation.
Paragraphs are short — 2-4 sentences max. Dense paragraphs kill the reading experience.
Use em dashes sparingly but effectively for emphasis and asides.
Never use the phrase 'data-driven' — show it, don't label it.
The word 'we' is used occasionally and naturally to create a sense of shared investigation ('We looked closer', 'We pulled the numbers').
seo_rules: Title must include the primary keyword naturally — player name, tournament name, or stat concept.
Meta description: 150-160 chars, includes the hook and primary keyword.
H1 matches the title exactly. H2s include secondary keywords where natural.
First paragraph should contain the primary keyword within the first two sentences.
Use player full names on first reference, then last name only.
Include tournament name, course name, and year for time-sensitive content.
URL slug: lowercase, hyphenated, concise (3-6 words ideal).
Alt text for hero images should be descriptive and include player/event name.

image_strategy.hero_fallback: When no real photo is available, use the gradient placeholder: background: linear-gradient(140deg, #0f1a16 0%, #162420 50%, #0a0a0a 100%)
image_strategy.note: Generated posts use gradient hero backgrounds by default. Real photos can be swapped in manually later.
